confession.seduction_context: She was in woods feeling angry about a lawsuit with Nicolas Boulengier, then maire of Aydoilles, who had called her witch. A whirlwind blew up, then a man appeared who asked her what was wrong. She gave varying accounts of whether he visited her at home or only in the woods.

witnesses.name: Jean Mengin
witnesses.location: native of Aydoilles, now of Jeuxey

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her husband caught Marie taking apples from their garden and took her scarf as a pledge
He reproached Marie, Georgette, and Bastienne for causing his horse's death and called them witches
testimony.threat_quote: elle l'en feroit repentir et creveroit tous autres qui l'entreprendroient, adjoustante que tant qu'elle d'eust vivre elle en hayroit luy qui parle et s'en souviendroit

testimony.quarrel_subject: Marie and husband were taking earth from her father's adjoining land while digging their garden
Marie's husband had agreed to buy wheat from witness, they went to drink on the deal, but Marie protested saying she could find wheat without paying for wine
He laughed on seeing her tangled up with a scarf while drawing water; she complained about this to other women

harms_alleged.target: Mengeote (his sister and Marie's husband's sister)

testimony.quarrel_subject: He refused to loan them straw, and she admired his small bull as it passed
Her husband quarreled with Marie when she took pears from a tree in which they claimed a half share; witness (pregnant) became involved
testimony.threat_quote: que mal griefve joie peut elle avoir du fruict

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: First interrogation - she denied all charges despite accusations by stepmother

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Questioned about taking bones from cemetery; admitted taking bone from beside mother's grave on advice of late Halbix Thouvenin to treat sick child

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; made some minor admissions

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire after confrontation with stepmother

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves torture

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - would confess nothing despite full battery of tortures (thumbscrews, rack, strappado with stone attached)

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: PG des Vosges recommends she be released (renvoyée) with permission for Jean de Cugney to bring forward additional witnesses

timeline.subject: Jean de Cugney
timeline.details: Request from Jean de Cugney to bring forward further evidence and keep Marie in prison

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves keeping her in prison

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Costs guaranteed by Nicolas Demengeon against sureties from de Cugney and Demenge Thomas

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: New informations - 22 witnesses testified

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Interrogation and confrontations - continued to deny everything of significance

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: More confrontations with witnesses

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Final confrontations with witnesses

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for renewed torture

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves renewed torture

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Second interrogation under torture - began to confess after thumbscrews, gave fuller confession after being racked

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Confirmed earlier confessions, added nothing of significance

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Confirmation of sentence from bons hommes jugeants

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Prévôt validates claim by Jean de Cugney for expenses of 300 fr to be charged against Marie's goods

timeline.subject: Marie Plaid
timeline.details: Controlleur at Bruyeres authorized levy against goods, noting they were not sufficient to cover whole sum

accomplices_named.context: Named during confession as one of only accomplices she knew, along with Georgette

accomplices_named.name: Georgette (half-sister)
accomplices_named.context: Named during confession as one of only accomplices she knew, along with stepmother

prior_accusations.context: Accused Marie during her own trial
Accused Marie during her own trial
Also accused Marie (mentioned in Jean de Cugney's request)

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Thiriot
notable_quotes.french: elle l'en feroit repentir et creveroit tous autres qui l'entreprendroient, adjoustante que tant qu'elle d'eust vivre elle en hayroit luy qui parle et s'en souviendroit
notable_quotes.english: she would make him repent and burst all others who would undertake it, adding that as long as she lived she would hate him and remember it
notable_quotes.context: Marie's threat after Jean Thiriot called her and her family witches

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie Plaid
notable_quotes.french: que puis qu'on avoit donné argent audit Cugney pour aller au devin, ou en pelerinage, on leur en debvoit bien faire payer leur part
notable_quotes.english: since they had given money to said Cugney to go to the diviner or on pilgrimage, they should make them pay their part
notable_quotes.context: Marie's comment about Adeline Cugney's bull death

notable_quotes.speaker: Mongeote femme Demenge Colas Goherey
notable_quotes.french: que mal griefve joie peut elle avoir du fruict
notable_quotes.english: what grievous evil joy she may have from the fruit
notable_quotes.context: Marie's threat to pregnant witness during quarrel over pears

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine fille Demenge Mengin
notable_quotes.context: Marie's words after Dieudonné Barbas took her scarf as pledge - he died a fortnight later

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Francois le jeune
notable_quotes.french: le malin esprit la vouloit tuer et la pressoit fort
notable_quotes.english: the evil spirit wanted to kill her and pressed her hard
notable_quotes.context: Marie's cry in prison two weeks before additional witnesses testified

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie Plaid
notable_quotes.french: par mesgard et pour avoir mal entendu
notable_quotes.english: by inadvertence and for having misunderstood
notable_quotes.context: Her excuse for denying certain testimony during confrontations

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie Plaid
notable_quotes.french: mesme fait mine d'estre troublée de l'esprit, par plusieurs discours et paroles qu'elle tient hors de propos
notable_quotes.english: even pretends to be troubled in spirit, by several discourses and words she holds out of place
notable_quotes.context: Description of her behavior after first torture session when urged to confess

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean de Cugney
notable_quotes.french: qui pour un zelle que la justice soit faicte afin non seulement de se delivrer quand a luy de leurs malefices dont il a resenty des pertes, Mais encor le Publicque, et pour purger leur village de telle semence pernitieuse
notable_quotes.english: who with zeal that justice be done in order not only to deliver himself from their malefices from which he has suffered losses, but also the Public, and to purge their village of such pernicious seed
notable_quotes.context: Jean de Cugney's justification for bringing forward additional witnesses

relationships.evidence_text: married to Demenge Jean Plaid from Moriviller

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over resources: straw loans refused, wheat sales disputed, cart loan refused, property boundaries (taking earth from neighbor's land), shared fruit tree ownership disputed. Jean de Cugney claimed losses of 500 francs from animal deaths and spent 300 francs on prosecution costs (charged against Marie's goods which were insufficient to cover the amount).

material_culture.context: Dieudonné Barbas took Marie's scarf as pledge after catching her taking apples; later she was seen tangled with scarf while drawing water
Stolen from gardens, used in alleged healings/poisonings, given to Mengeote who died
Disputed ownership of pears from shared tree; allegedly cured Nicolas Humbert Cugney by giving him a pear
Caught taking two plums from Dieudonné Barbay's garden
Took bone from beside mother's grave on advice of Halbix Thouvenin to treat sick child with fever
Given to Nicolas Anthoine's bull, allegedly to cure it but it died
Given to Laurence Anthoine, taken from sister's garden, told her to conceal it
Evil-smelling drug she had three weeks before interrogation, said it was to prevent animals dying
Used in mixture to treat Laurence Prevost's chest condition
Mixed with lard and egg yolk to treat illness
Mixed with lard and holy water for medical treatment
Claimed these were marine bones brought from St Jacques pilgrimage, powdered and mixed with lard for healing
Stepmother confessed they gave horse grain mixed with powder to kill it
Mixed with powder allegedly to kill horse; also subject of disputes (wheat purchases)
Subject of multiple disputes - refused loans led to animal deaths
Husband refused loan of cart, led to heifer death
Refused butter at Demenge Thomas's house, led to horse death
Subject of dispute between husband and Colas Andreu
Dispute over payment for wine in wheat deal with Bastien Lalleman
Abandoned her bundle to go home empty-handed from woods
Husband bought cloth she was washing in small hours; bone wrapped in cloth to treat child
Put hands on holy scriptures to swear she acted with good intention
Ox had to be fetched home on planks after being near Marie's house

religious_calendar_references: feast-day (when they sinned going to woods)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Lawsuit between Marie and husband versus Nicolas Boulengier (then maire of Aydoilles) who had called her witch. This occurred about 2 years before trial (around 1617-1618) and allegedly triggered her seduction by the devil.

legal_context.redress_outcome: Marie confessed under torture that this lawsuit was the precipitating event for her seduction - while angry about being called witch, devil appeared to her in woods
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Held in prison for extended period (Oct 21, 1619 to execution in early 1620). Prison guard Mengeon Francois testified she cried out that evil spirit wanted to kill her and pressed her hard. She was moved to another place after this. Later told guard she was tired of prison and wanted to confess. After first torture, pretended to be troubled in spirit with inappropriate speech.

hearsay_chains.content: Story about Marie taking bones from cemetery
Previous evidence over death of calf
What had been said about her in the fields
Marie complained to other women about Claudon Ferry laughing at her
Story of treatment of Jacat Doron's child
Marie's late mother was greatly feared as witch
Heard of threats by Bastienne after husband caught Marie stealing apples

emotional_state_notes: denied charges despite accusations by stepmother
pretended to be troubled in spirit with inappropriate speech after first torture
cried out in prison that evil spirit wanted to kill her and pressed her hard
told guard she was tired of prison and would confess
said she wished to die as stepmother and sister had done
gave varying and equivocal statements during second torture
said when she told truth no-one wanted to believe her

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said she denied words at bedside of sick child 'par mesgard et pour avoir mal entendu' (by inadvertence and for having misunderstood)
Denied living together with stepmother, said they lived in different parts of house
Said Jean Villaume's wife told her about what had been said in the fields (defending how she knew about gossip)

extraction_metadata.notes: This trial is notable for Marie's resistance to torture - she confessed nothing during the first full torture session (thumbscrews, rack, strappado with stone) and was initially recommended for release. Only after Jean de Cugney petitioned to bring 22 additional witnesses and second torture was applied did she finally confess. The trial demonstrates the family cluster pattern - Marie was accused by her already-executed stepmother and half-sister. The informations are missing, so evidence comes from trials of stepmother and half-sister. Extensive catalog of maleficia involving primarily animal deaths following quarrels over resources. Trial lasted 114 days from first interrogation to final property confiscation order. Property confiscated but insufficient to cover prosecution costs of 300 francs.
